document.masterDocTitle: Larval Morphology of Armostus ohyamatensis Hoshina and Satô (Coleoptera: Hydrophilidae: Megasternini)

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Larval Morphology of Armostus ohyamatensis Hoshina and Satô (Coleoptera: Hydrophilidae: Megasternini)

subSubSection.paragraph:
Armostus ohyamatensis Hoshina and Satô, 2006
( Figs. 1–8 )
Material Examined. One L1: YNME #16-16; two L3: YNME #16-1, 16-15 (see Table 1 ).
Additional Material Examined. One L3, one L2: Loc. #2016-11, collected together with YNME #16-15, 16-16 (see Table 1 ).

caption.paragraph:
Fig. 1. Larvae and collecting localities of
Armostus ohyamatensis
. A) Third instar habitus, ventral and dorsal views, B) Third instar, posteromesal surface of head capsule, dorsal view (FR1 = frontale setae, FR2 = frontale pores, PA7 and PA8 = parietale setae), C) Third instar, posterolateral surface of head capsule, dorsal view D) Third instar, anteromesal surface of prothorax, dorsal view E) Third instar, dorsal plate of spiracular atrium (t = trachea), F) First instar, dorsal plate of spiracular atrium, G) Collecting locality Loc.#2016-8, H) Collecting locality Loc.#2016-11 (same as Loc.#2017-23). A–E = larva YNME#16-1; F = larva YNME#16-16.

Fig. 2.
Armostus ohyamatensis
, first instar YNME#16-16, head capsule. A) Dorsal view, B) Arrangement of sensilla PA1–7 on left side, C) Ventral view, D) Anterior margin, dorsal view. gFR = group of sensilla on frontale; FR = frontale; LA = labium; PA = parietale. Fine surface structures are omitted.

subSubSection.paragraph: Primary Chaetotaxy of Head. Frontale ( Fig. 2A, D ): Rather long seta FR1 on posterior fourth, close to frontal line; pore-like sensillum FR2 and short seta FR3 on midlength of head capsule,

caption.paragraph:
Fig. 3.
Armostus ohyamatensis
, first instar YNME#16-16, head appendages. A) Antenna, dorsal view, B–C) Mandibles, dorsal view, D) Left stipes, dorsal view, E–F) Right stipes, dorsal (E) and ventral (F) views, G–H) Labium, dorsal (G) and ventral (H) views. AN = antenna; gAN = group of the apical antennal sensilla; gAPP = group of sensilla on inner appendage of maxilla; gLA = group of the apical sensilla on labial palpus; gMX2 = group of sensilla on inner face of stipes; LA = labium; MN = mandible; MX = maxilla; SE = sensorium.

subSubSection.paragraph: posteromesal to FR5. Long seta FR5 and rather short seta FR6 behind antennal socket, FR6 lateral to FR5. Pore-like sensillum FR4 posteromesal to antennal socket. Position of sensilla on anterior part of frontale asymmetrical. Right side: Aggregated sensilla FR8–10 and FR14 anteromesal to antennal socket; short seta FR10 behind moderately long setae FR8 and FR9, FR8 mesal to FR9. Pore-like sensillum FR14 close to inner margin of antennal socket. Short seta FR 12 anterior to FR8, pore-like sensillum FR13 posteromesal to FR12, FR11 may be absent (see Remarks). Pore-like sensillum FR15 posterolateral to egg burster. Left side: Aggregated sensilla FR8–10 and FR12–14 anteromesal to antennal socket; FR14 very close to inner margin of antennal socket; FR9 between FR14 and FR8; FR10 behind FR8, FR12 and FR13 anterior to FR9 and FR8 respectively. FR15 posterolateral to egg burster. gFR1 with 5 setae on anterior margin and 2 minute setae below egg bursters.

Maxilla ( Fig. 3D–F ): Cardo with 1 ventral seta ( MX 1). Inner face of stipes with a row of 8 stout setae, possible MX 7 at base, remaining 7 forming gMX2. Part of gMX2 on right maxilla with subapical tooth (often undetectable due to direction of seta). Pore-like sensilla MX 2–4 on ventral face; MX 2 on median part, MX 3 on apical fourth of inner face, MX 4 on subapical part of lateral face of sclerite. Long seta MX 5 and short seta MX 6 situated laterally and subapically on sclerite. Dorsal surface of palpomere 1 with 1 short seta ( MX 16) situated basally on inner face. MX 12–14 located ventrally on anterior part of sclerite; MX 12 pore-like on lateral part, very long seta MX 13 and rather long seta MX 14 on midwidth. Pore-like sensillum MX 15 situated ventrally behind gAPP. MX 17 absent. Four setae of variable length and shape (gAPP) present apically on inner face of intersegmental membrane between palpomeres 1 and 2. Palpomere 2 with 2 pore-like sensilla ( MX 18, MX 19) and 1 minute seta ( MX 27). PA18 on lateral face, PA19 on inner face of intersegmental membrane between palpomeres 2 and 3; MX 27 located proximally on lateral face. Palpomere 3 with 2 pore-like sensilla ( MX 20 and MX 22), and long ( MX 21) and very long ( MX 23) setae. MX 23 on midlength of lateral face; MX 20–22 on ventral face, MX 20 on lateral part, MX 21 on inner part, MX 22 on median part. Palpomere 4 with 1 short seta ( MX 24), and digitiform ( MX 25) and pore-like ( MX 26) sensilla; MX 24 situated proximally on inner face; MX 25 and MX 26 dorsally on lateral ( MX 26) and median ( MX 25) parts. Apical membranous area of palpomere 4 with several minute setae (gMX).

Description of Second Instar. General morphology and chaetotaxy of L2 very similar to L3. Frontal lines clearly visible. Head capsule covered with microtrichiae and with granulate posterolateral face, but both finer and weaker than in L3.
Description of Third instar. General Morphology. Body ( Fig. 1A ) light yellowish white, moderately flat, maggot-like in shape, widest in posterior half.

Antenna ( Fig. 6A ): Three-segmented; surface smooth. Antennomere 1 longest and widest, antennomere 3 shortest and narrowest. Approximate ratios of length of antennomeres 1–3 as follows: 1.0:0.6:0.3 ( n = 1). Antennal sensorium present, long.

caption.paragraph:
Fig. 4. Larvae of
Armostus ohyamatensis
. A) Third instar YNME#16-15 (broken parts modified), head, dorsal view, B) Third instar, thorax, dorsal view, C) Third instar, prosternal sclerite, ventral view, D) First instar YNME#16- 16, anterior leg, ventral view, E) Third instar, anterior leg, ventral view, F) Third instar YNME#16-1, spiracular atrium, dorsal view. l = lateral lobe of spiracular atrium; m = median lobe of spiracular atrium; p = procercus; sp = spiracle; t = trachea. Fine surface structures are omitted.

Fig. 5.
Armostus ohyamatensis
, third instar YNME#16-1, head capsule. A) Dorsal view, B) Ventral view, C) Anterior margin, dorsal view. gFR = group of sensilla on frontale; FR = frontale; LA = labium; PA = parietale. Fine surface structures are omitted.

Fig. 6.
Armostus ohyamatensis
, third instar YNME#16-1, head appendages. A) Antenna, dorsal view, B–C) Mandibles, dorsal view, D) Inner margin of right mandible, dorsal view, different direction from C. AN = antenna; gAN = group of the apical antennal sensilla; MN = mandible; SE = sensorium.

Fig. 7.
Armostus ohyamatensis
, third instar. A) Left maxilla, dorsal surface, B) Left maxilla, ventral surface, C) Right maxilla, dorsal surface, D) Right maxilla, ventral surface. All drawn from dorsal view. gAPP = group of sensilla on inner appendage of maxilla; gMX2 = group of sensilla on inner face of stipes.

subSubSection.paragraph: Abdomen ( Figs. 1A, E , 4F ): Ten-segmented, broad; membranous parts densely covered with microtrichiae. Segments 1–7 similar to each other, with 1 pair of weakly tuberculate spiracles laterally. Spiracular atrium ( Figs. 1E , 4F ) with dorsal plate very large, suboval, covered with microtrichiae and numerous sensilla ( Fig. 1E ). Posterior edge of dorsal plate sinuate, with triangular posterior projection medially; sinuation and size of triangular projection variable. 1 pair of large spiracles present in spiracular atrium. Procercus moderate in size, inner face partly sclerotized, narrowing apically. Segment 9 trilobed, with a pair of 1-segmented, sclerotized urogomphi bearing a very long seta. Lateral lobe larger than procercus, partly sclerotized. Acrocercus absent. Median lobe broader than lateral lobe, dorsal surface sclerotized medially.
Biology. Adults and larvae were collected from leaf litter ( Fig. 1G, H ) (Hoshina and Satô 2006a).

Remarks. Megasternini are the most genus-rich group within the Hydrophilidae (Short and Fikáček 2011, 2013). This indicates that the adults of Megasternini are morphologically highly diverse. However, their larval morphology is similar among the genera ( Archangelsky 2016 ). Larval morphology of
Armostus
is especially similar to that of
Cercyon
and
Cryptopleurum
. Differences in larval morphology among
Armostus
and the other two genera are mostly ambiguous, but there is a significant difference: the incompletely cylindrically sclerotized maxillary palpomere 2 ( Figs. 3E , 7A, C ), which is unique to
A. ohyamatensis
among the known larvae of Hydrophilidae . Although maxillary palpomeres sometimes can be incompletely sclerotized in hydrophilid larvae, this character state has always been observed in palpomere 1 in other genera ( e.g. , Archangelsky 1997 ; Minoshima and Hayashi 2011).

caption.paragraph:
Fig. 8.
Armostus ohyamatensis
, third instar YNME#16-1. A) Labium, ventral view, B) Labial palpus, ventral view.

subSubSection.paragraph:
Larval chaetotaxy of megasternine genera remains largely unknown.
Cercyon
is the only genus for which the chaetotaxy has been described ( Fikáček 2006 ;
Fikáček et al. 2008
; Archangelsky 2016 ). Based on our study, the chaetotaxy of
Armostus
and
Cercyon
are similar, but several differences are observed. A group of setae, gFR1, seems to differ within the genus, composed of seven setae in
Armostus
( Fig. 2D ) but seven or eight in
Cercyon ( Archangelsky 2016 )
.
Fikáček et al. (2008)
treated gFR as the setae on the anterior margin only, thus they might report the number as five. Homology of the pores FR11 and FR13 is uncertain, and I assumed the pore close to FR12 as FR13 based on its position ( Fig. 2D ). In this context, FR11 is absent in
Armostus
, whereas it is present in
Cercyon
(
Fikáček et al. 2008
; Archangelsky 2016 ). However, the FR11-like (secondary) pore appears in L2 and L3, anterior to “FR13” on the right side; homology of the pore is unclear. PA12–14 are closely aggregated in
Cercyon
but rather loosely distributed in
Armostus
; they are therefore homologized in
Armostus
( Fig. 2A ). This character is similar to that of
Pelosoma ( Archangelsky 2016 )
. The maxillary setae (gMX) are in an irregular, longitudinal row in
Armostus
( Fig. 3D, E ), whereas they comprise two groups (basal four and distal three) in
Cercyon quisquilius (Linnaeus) ( Archangelsky 2016 )
.

On the other hand,
Armostus
larvae share the potential synapomorphies of Megasternini proposed by Archangelsky (2016) except for the: arrangement of PA12–14 (see above); presence of an additional pore on the base of antennomere 2 ( Figs. 3A , 6A ); basal setae of gMX2 on the left maxilla arranged in an oblique row (fewer setae than
Cercyon
) ( Figs. 3D , 7A ); gMX composed of 5–9 setae ( 7 in
Armostus
)); and reduced legs ( Fig. 4D, E ). In addition, Archangelsky (2016) mentioned the stipital asymmetry in the tribes Megasternini and Sphaeridiini , which is also observed in
Armostus
( Figs. 3D, E , 7 ). Besides Megasternini and Sphaeridiini , asymmetrical stipes are observed in the rygmodine genera
Andotypus Spangler, 1979
and
Austrotypus Fikáček, Minoshima, and Newton, 2014
(
Fikáček et al. 2014
). However, the asymmetry is only apparent in the outline of the stipes in Rygmodinae , whereas it is seen in the outline, shape of the sclerite, and arrangement of cuticular hairs in Megasternini .
